articles.title: A Blog Post with Every HTML Element?¬†Almost.
articles.description: Taking 18 months to come together, this post makes a brave attempt to squeeze every HTML element (including some former elements like <marquee> and <blink>) into a single place. It‚Äôs a fantastically retro-feeling reunion that starts off feeling a little dull but rapidly picks up the pace, even if poor <applet> doesn't make the cut..
articles.author: Patrick Weaver

articles.title: WordPress 6.3 ‚ÄúLionel‚Äù Released
articles.description: Hailed as a ‚Äúmomentous release‚Äù, the universally popular CMS includes a new Site Editor experience, the ability to create and sync block ‚Äòpatterns‚Äô, new design tools, keyboard shortcut changes, style revision tracking, along with performance and accessibility improvements.
articles.author: Mat√≠as Ventura (WordPress)

articles.title: An Update on Chrome Security Updates: Shipping Security Fixes to You Faster
articles.description: In an effort to reduce the ‚Äúpatch gap‚Äù and get security fixes out faster, Chrome is now shipping weekly Stable channel updates. This doesn't affect the cadence of milestone updates, though, so Chrome 200 is still some way off. ü§≠
articles.author: Amy Ressler (Google)

articles.title: Introducing Project IDX: An Experiment to Improve Full-Stack, Multiplatform App Development
articles.description: A new project from Google ‚Äî it‚Äôs a full browser-based IDE (built atop the same tech as VS Code) that includes support for most full-stack JavaScript frameworks, cross-platform previews, and deploying to Firebase. You can sign up for the waitlist.
articles.author: Google

articles.title: An Introduction to htmx, the HTML-Oriented Dynamic UI Library
articles.description: A look at what htmx is, how it aims to simplify dynamic web development, and how you can harness its potential to enhance your web development process.
articles.author: James Hibbard

articles.title: ‚ú® ¬†Coding the Stars: An Interactive Constellation with React Three¬†Fiber
articles.description: The Supabase team built a Web-based visualization in the form of an animated sky filled with stars, where each star represented a user signup. If you‚Äôve never experimented with React Three Fiber or creating visual effects before, this is a good introduction walking through the key parts of their approach.
articles.author: Francesco Sansalvadore (Supabase)

articles.title: What Does It Mean for Web Browsers to Have a 'Baseline'
articles.description: Back in May we shared news on Baseline, a new project that aims to clarify what developers can rely on across browsers and the web platform in general. Mary recaps why it matters, how it will hopefully work, and even touches upon the browser politics of the new project.
articles.author: Mary Branscombe (The New Stack)

articles.title: Smoothing Out the Scrolling Experience in Chrome on Android
articles.description: A look at how the scrolling experience on Chrome for Android has been improved, reducing slow scrolling jank by 2x. The post shares how the Chromium team discovered and evaluated the problem, and how that helped them ‚Äúdesign a better browser experience going forward‚Äù.
articles.author: Stephen Nusko (Google)

articles.title: Optimizing Speed on eBay
articles.description: ‚ÄúFor every 100 milliseconds improvement in search page loading time, eBay saw a 0.5% increase in ‚ÄòAdd to Cart‚Äô count.‚Äù ‚Äî This perfectly highlights how important performance can be at such huge scale. Addy runs through just how the performance of eBay‚Äôs sites and apps were optimized for a faster overall user experience.
articles.author: Addy Osmani

articles.title: Designing Accessible Text Over Images: Best Practices, Techniques, And Resources
articles.description: The first in a two-part series in which Hannah Milan covers best practices when using various 'text over image' techniques. Lots of visuals here to help make the point.
articles.author: Smashing Magazine

articles.title: Typograms: A Way to Render ASCII Diagrams More Elegantly
articles.description: An intriguing project out of Google that lets you ‚Äòdraw‚Äô diagrams in plain ASCII text within special script tags and these will then be rendered into nicer looking versions in the browser. An interesting approach if Mermaid is too full on for your needs.
articles.author: Sam Goto / Google

articles.title: svg-drawing: A Simple Canvas to Draw, "Replay", and Export SVG Line Art
articles.description: You can deep link to any drawing, adjust some draw settings, and even change the options for playing back the drawing by animating the lines. Please excuse my shoddy rocket drawing.
articles.author: catsjuice

articles.title: OGL 1.0: A Minimal WebGL Framework
articles.description: WebGL is far from the easiest technology to use on its own, so libraries like Three.js are often used to make it more accessible. OGL has a similar motive while sticking closer to the WebGL metal.
articles.author: Nathan Gordon et al.

articles.title: Vaul: An Unstyled Drawer Component for React
articles.description: Also referred to as a ‚Äúbottom sheet‚Äù, useful for mobile interfaces as a replacement for a dialog element and it‚Äôs powered by Radix UI‚Äôs dialog component.
articles.author: Emil Kowalski

articles.title: Mobile FIRST: A Browser Extension to Simulate Different Mobile¬†Devices
articles.description: Available for Chrome and Firefox, it‚Äôs useful for responsive testing and taking screenshots and GIFs for mockups and presentations.
articles.author: Mobile FIRST

articles.title: MyTailwind: Interactively Customize Tailwind Components
articles.description: Gives you a simple visual editor where you can customize styles for about 11 different components (button, navbar, card, sidebar, alert, etc.), then copy the HTML with the Tailwind classes.
articles.author: Ashraful Malik

articles.title: noclip ‚Äî¬†A Digital Web-Based Museum of Video Game¬†Levels
articles.description: This neat site is a browser-based way to explore levels from a variety of classic games. I‚Äôve just been exploring the castle grounds of Super Mario 64 and the streets of GTA III‚Äôs Liberty City. A cool nostalgia trip if nothing else. Repo here. Three cheers for WebGL!
articles.author: Jasper St. Pierre

articles.description: You may start to see OpenAI's 'GPTBot' in your logs, as the company recently launched its own web crawler which in turn sparked blocking efforts by website owners and creators.
Fran√ßois Beaufort shares what's new in WebGPU in Chrome, including WebCodecs integration, video playback improvements, and more.
What's the biggest, valid z-index value you can specify in CSS? It may be ‚ñ∂Ô∏è larger than you think.
The way in which downloads appear in Chrome has changed.
A request has been made for the Chromium project to reconsider JPEG-XL support (which it had sought to not support). Lots of related chatter on Hacker News about this one.
